system_overview: A mobile-first Contextual Integrity worksheet operationalizing Mulligan/Koopman/Doty's multi-dimensional privacy framework for practical use in design meetings.

organizing_principles.current: CI framework is academic, not operational
organizing_principles.intervention: Mobile-first interface that fits in pocket

information_flows.current: Privacy discussed abstractly or not at all in design meetings
information_flows.target: Specific dimensions raised during actual work
information_flows.intervention: Label/Deck/Learn views for different meeting contexts

system_infrastructure.target: Single-file HTML that works on any phone

dynamic_processes.embedded_values: Design meetings prioritize speed; privacy seen as blocker
dynamic_processes.process_redesign_opportunity: Privacy dimensions as design prompts, not obstacles

social_positionalities.power_dynamics: UX researchers may lack authority to raise privacy concerns
social_positionalities.safety_concerns: Raising privacy can be seen as slowing project
social_positionalities.legitimized_expertise: Tool legitimizes UX/research voice on privacy (not just legal)

invisible_work.articulation_labor: Translating CI theory into actionable dimensions
invisible_work.emotional_labor: Advocating for privacy in speed-focused culture

embedded_systems.economic_logics: Data monetization incentives conflict with privacy
embedded_systems.legal_context: Contextual Integrity as emerging legal framework

integrated_intervention_strategies.infrastructure_work: Make academic framework operational; provide Label/Deck/Learn views for different contexts
Create feedback loop—suggest commonly-missed dimensions based on domain

integrated_intervention_strategies.intervention: Auto-populate labels from observed data flows
integrated_intervention_strategies.infrastructure_work: Level 2 trail integration—compare intended vs actual information sharing

invisible_trail: Observing UX designers struggling with privacy in meetings

meta_rule: Analyze privacy tools by asking: What paradigm governs privacy (compliance vs. design material), AND what infrastructural conditions (meeting formats, power dynamics, economic incentives) make privacy advocacy possible or impossible?
